explanation:
Correct calculation: \( 500{,}000 \, \text{cm}^3 \div 1000 = 500 \, \text{L} \).

Student's likely calculation: \( 500{,}000 \, \text{cm}^3 \div 100 = 5000 \, \text{L} \).

The student incorrectly divided by 100 instead of 1000 when converting cubic centimeters to liters. This indicates a misunderstanding of the relationship between liters and cubic centimeters: they used a divisor corresponding to a linear (100 cm/m) rather than volumetric (1000 cm³/L) conversion. The error aligns with dividing by 100 instead of 1000, as their answer is exactly 10 times larger than the correct value. 

This differs from the misconception "1L = 10,000 cm³" (which would yield 50L) or "1L = 10 cm³" (yielding 50,000L). The error specifically stems from misapplying a two-order-of-magnitude divisor rather than three, distinct from other listed volume-conversion errors.
